newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Belarus-Russia deal costly for Moscow - spokesman.
newsitem.headline: Belarus-Russia deal costly for Moscow - spokesman.

text.p: A controversial draft pact which would commit Russia and Belarus to a close union could worsen Russia's strained finances, the chief government spokesman said on Tuesday.

Igor Shabdurasulov told a news conference that the draft Union Treaty was not yet ready -- a day before President Boris Yeltins and Belarus President Alexander Lukashenko were expected to meet in Moscow to sign it.
"It (the agreement) means taking away some financial resources," Shabdurasulov said. "To a certain extent it will make the financial situation in Russia more complicated."
"Even on April 1 this document cannot be considered ready for signing. Even today very serious work is continuing."
The document provides for close coordination of foreign, military and economic policies between the two former Soviet republics. But it stops short of merging the Slav neighbours into a single state.

Shabdurasulov's remarks appeared to reflect a struggle in Russia's political elite over the draft, which was prepared by Russian and Belarus teams behind closed doors. The official text of the draft treaty has not been published.

Russian liberals have urged Yeltsin not to strike any deal with Lukashenko, a hardliner who has cracked down on his political opponents and expelled a U.S. diplomat, accusing him of interfering in internal affairs.

Yeltsin on Wednesday dispatched security adviser Ivan Rybkin to Minsk to talk to Lukashenko. "He is charged with meeting...Lukashenko and handing him a message from the president of Russia," the Kremlin press service said.
